I have had 10 involuntary hospital admissions in Australia and New Zealand which are similar processes to the 5150s with the 72 hour holds except in my circumstances they decided every time I was too unwell to leave and made me stay 2 weeks to 3 months each admission. They can be really traumatic. I have a lot of trauma surrounding how I was treated by staff and what I have witnessed in those wards so I don #8217;t doubt that she could very well have some trauma from her 5150. When you are an involuntary patient you lose all your rights and they can do anything really. The stories I could tell I could probably write I book - all up I have probably spent at least 9-10 months possibly longer in those hospitals against my will. Two of those were 3 months long.

All programs I have been to strongly recommend we don #8217;t keep in contact with people we meet in them actually. It is highly discouraged to give our personal information to other people in the groups or hospitals at every one I have been at and I #8217;ve been to a lot to protect patients. Some people do end up making friends but it is usually highly discouraged to protect patients.

For something like this you should go if you feel like you need to go. If you have been thinking about returning then you could ask if an admission would be good for you. You know you best. There isn #8217;t anything black and white on when to seek help except always go if you feel you are a danger to yourself or others - other than that it #8217;s up to you and knowing yourself and when you need help. Where I live in Australia we have public hospitals and private, not sure what it #8217;s like where you are. The public ones people generally go if they need acute care and are generally a danger to themselves - I #8217;ve been n involuntary patient there many time #8217;s. Sometimes held against my will for up to 3 and a half months. These are generally not great for long term care but more for keeping you safe when you are in a crisis. Then we also have private hospitals that have group therapy programs that anyone with mental health or addiction programs can go whenever they feel that it might benefit them - they just need a referral from their doctor. These can be quite beneficial - I #8217;ve been to quite a few private hospitals - I stay there instead of going involuntary now as long as I can ensure my safety as I have a lot of trauma from involuntary.

Private is very expensive, if you don #8217;t have insurance you have to pay a lot of money for it. It #8217;s thousands a day. A lot of people can #8217;t afford it. I #8217;m lucky my insurance covers it. Some are good and some are pretty bad depending on where you go. I #8217;ve been to a few different ones and they #8217;ve all been different. The public hospitals are not nice where I was held involuntarily for months on end and I have a lot of trauma from them.

Sometimes when you #8217;re not eating enough calories you can end up binging which she would probably keep to herself out of shame and guilt. Some people will just binge and some may try and counteract with things like laxatives, purging, exercise but you will often still gain weight from a binge even if you try and counteract with something and if the scale says you lost weight after and you used laxatives or purging it would often be water weight - if she is having problems with binging that could be a reason why her weight is staying the same. She probably feels extremely self conscious about her weight and the fact that she isn #8217;t losing as quickly as she likes. I wouldn #8217;t jump directly to lying - some people #8217;s eating disorders can change and morph over time as well instead of just staying the same so you can start by restricting and restricting only and then you can start having problems with binging or binge purging etc. I would just be there for her.

In regards to a psych ward, they won #8217;t put you in one involuntarily unless you are a severe risk of harm to yourself or others - generally this is a suicidal plan with intent in the near future - suicidal thoughts that are passive will not get you admitted, you need a plan with the intent to follow through for them to be able to admit you against your will. I #8217;ve been involuntarily committed 10 times. In regards to the police I #8217;m not certain on that - I would think they wouldn #8217;t breach confidentiality unless you were a danger to yourself or it was a serious charge that it was putting someone else in danger like a violent sort of crime, a felony etc. Things like drugs they wouldn #8217;t report you to the police for as they deal with people in addiction all the time, not sure how the confidentiality would work with you being a minor though as to whether they would breach confidentiality for that. They generally will tell your parents if they are concerned for your safety e.g they #8217;re concerned you #8217;ll commit suicide, seriously injure yourself. Mine never told my parents when I self harmed - that stayed confidential. But honestly you are going there to get help. It #8217;s best to talk about everything. This is the biggest joke ever. And most people that have depression don #8217;t actually need a psychiatric ward - they are fine with psychotherapy and potentially medications. Inpatient is generally reserved for people that have severe suicidal intent and there are some private wards that do have group therapy programs for depression but generally you go when you #8217;re a danger to yourself or others. This is a joke as someone that has actually been to wards involuntary against my will under involuntary treatment orders in my country (like a baker act/5150 sort of thing the US has) and done group programs in private wards. Actually most people with depression are far better off just with psychotherapy and sometimes medication. These hospitals can actually be pretty traumatising and I have seen a lot of horrible things and have a lot of trauma from those wards and also how I have been treated. Inpatient/ #8220;mental hospital #8221; is generally reserved for people who are a severe risk of harming themselves or others. You generally need to be severely suicidal and have a plan and intent, even passive suicidal thoughts won #8217;t get you in involuntarily - I have had 10 involuntary admissions. Beds are tight and I know where I live they will turn you away if you are not severe enough (I never have been turned away, I was always dragged there but I know of many people who have been turned away) - it #8217;s to contain the crisis not a fun happy place. There are also private psychiatric wards with group therapy programs which I have also attended that thankfully my insurance covers but these are expensive and not everyone can afford these. This is in Australia. But it #8217;s the Baker Act and 51/50s are still similar to our ITOs in the fact you have to be a severe risk of harming yourself or others which generally means you need a plan and intent or they need to believe there is a severe risk, just saying you have suicidal thoughts doesn #8217;t cut it.

It depends on the medication you are taking and how your body reacts. It #8217;s kind of taken me a while to work out how bpd fits for me. I always thought the first criteria for example never applied to me at the moment because I don #8217;t trust people and don #8217;t have relationships and then realised I don #8217;t have relationships so that I don #8217;t get abandoned. So that is technically a different way of the first criteria point manifesting it #8217;s just it #8217;s often seen where people will have relationships and will act out in fear of real or imagined abandonment. For me I don #8217;t have any relationships at all (except for my parents, sister and best friend who I know would never abandon me) and this is so I don #8217;t get abandoned. I have completely disconnected from everyone else. When I was a teenager my relationships were intense and I probably acted out more for fear of abandonment and then people abandoned me so much I didn #8217;t want to be abandoned any more and stopped all socialisation. It also took me a while to admit I split. My family don #8217;t notice it because I do it internally. My anger is usually internal. Very very strong but internal and I don #8217;t lash out and get angry most of the time when I do split (occasionally I do but usually I don #8217;t). Because I am autistic and I have very rigid black and white thinking and routine and way of life if someone breaks that or my expectations is when I will usually split. Then I kind of worked I meet most of them. I denied the anger one for a long time because I didn #8217;t want to admit I was angry but I get extreme internal anger - I just most of the time don #8217;t express it to other people so I didn #8217;t think it counted but it did because it can get bad. And how my mood can change quickly based on situations. A lot of the time I have a baseline flat mood thanks to depression though. I have an identity disturbance and have bounced around different things like what I want to be when I grow up, different religions, even whether I was trans (which I realised I personally am not, I was confused although I know people are legit trans and not confused). Different beliefs like if I #8217;m vegan or not. Self harm on and off from 12-22 and I #8217;ve been suicidal on and off 15 was my first involuntary hospitalisation which is a criteria. I can get paranoid when stressed and dissociate often. I often feel empty. And I am an extremely impulsive person. At the moment it #8217;s mainly spending which is only one and it #8217;s supposed to be two for diagnosis. But when I was driving I would drive recklessly which is 2. Also have had problems with different impulsive behaviours as well as spending at different times. Kind of taken me a while to admit I had bpd. Last month I was at my doctor crying trying to get my diagnosis removed because of the stigma I #8217;ve seen from people online and also from professionals who don #8217;t know me and just have straight away stigmatised you for having this disorder. I had one doctor who didn #8217;t really know me do a medical certificate up it was for government assistance and needed my diagnosis on it and he wrote in the bpd symptoms #8220;manipulative and other traits of bpd #8221; - he was a normal doctor not a psychiatrist and probably just knew of the stigma behind bpd but I felt horrible. But the more I look into it the more it makes sense. I was officially diagnosed when I was 18 and I #8217;m 22 now, every psychiatrist I #8217;ve had since 18 has said I #8217;m borderline before getting my records and they suspected I had it from 15 and I #8217;ve tried to deny it until now but I #8217;ve kind of got to accept it.

Personally I am not a fan of people self diagnosing themselves, not getting it confirmed by a professional and going around claiming to have the disorder. This is because it might not be the case and even things like depression might not actually be depression - you can have symptoms of depression from having a hypothyroid for example. So I think it is always important to consult a professional. I think it #8217;s fine to look things up and go #8220;I suspect I have this #8221; and then go seek a professional and ask them what they think and get an outside perspective and knowledge and tests but I hate people going around claiming to have disorders sometimes very complex ones without much knowledge on them without any interest in actually seeing a professional and getting it confirmed. There are many disorders that overlap especially in mental health and they might find that they actually thought they had one thing and it is actually another for example. It #8217;s especially important to get a professional diagnosis. Because I #8217;m sick of people that I see online with these massive lists of mental illnesses that they don #8217;t know much about that they #8217;ve self diagnosed themselves with and when you ask them if they #8217;re getting a diagnosis they say no and you ask them if they #8217;re going to try and get therapy for them at least (you can even do booklets at home for therapy) and they say no and it #8217;s like what is the point other than going around parading this list like having a bunch of mental illnesses is something cool to have.

If you were hospitalised in an involuntary ward Yes they can use needles only on patients that are involuntary. If you are a voluntary patient you are able to refuse treatment but if you are acting in a way where they think you should be involuntary and are a risk they can get a doctor to sign papers and make you involuntary (I have gone in voluntary before and they have made me an involuntary patient while in there). The sedation needle would be used if someone was violent, severely manic and wouldn #8217;t calm down and refused medication to calm them down things like that. I did have an experience on the ward where I was wrongfully threatened to be injected simply because I refused to take a benzodiazepine that was a prn medication that they wanted me to take because I was talking loudly and they just wanted me to be quiet. Was told that they were going to get security to hold me down so they could inject me - I have found there can be staff that can be quite abusive in the 10 involuntary admissions I #8217;ve had taking advantage on involuntary patients and their rights. They also made me stay for very long periods of time sometimes but I can be very high risk for long periods of time. I #8217;ve had two 3 and half month long stays involuntary against my will. I used to run out the doors when people would come through and they #8217;d have to get a one on one nurse to guard me and even watch me in the bathroom. It was horrible. You would #8217;ve be allowed your pill cutter on you. You could ask them to keep it in the medication room and they could use it in there. But I would assume they would have a pill cutter themselves. Some hospitals allow phones and some do not. It is completely up to hospital policy and isn #8217;t a black and white thing. In regards to needles as well you will get a blood test when you arrive on the ward as well.

I #8217;m In Australia too. The public ones were free for me but I was an involuntary patient and they will generally only take you if you are a severe risk of harm to yourself or others and are only a crisis containment point - they aren #8217;t there to make you better but to contain the crisis and send you on your way. I have had 9 admissions in public - most were in children #8217;s and some in adults. The things I witnessed there were traumatising and I was treated very badly. I had some very long admissions that were against my will, two were 3 and a half months long. You can go in voluntary which happened to me and then they decide you are too unwell to make your own decisions and make you involuntary and when you are involuntary you lose all rights to your own treatment. In Australia for involuntary treatment orders they can keep you for 72 hours then the psychiatrist reassess and then they can keep you for 6 more weeks, after that there is a tribunal hearing you go to on site and that is traumatising as well. I have gone to two of those and both said I had to stay and I was extremely upset. Then they can legally keep you for another 6 months I believe although I never was kept that long. Longest was 3 and a half months. If you really want to be in a ward I would only recommend private residential type places but they are expensive and you would need medical insurance for it. Those are voluntary only and you need to be safe for them - they won #8217;t take you if you are suicidal or self harming as they don #8217;t have the resources but offer extensive group therapy programs and psychiatric care. I have been in a few of them too. You get much better support in a place like that but unfortunately it #8217;s very expensive. But I really recommend outpatient therapy unless you are really in a life or death crisis in regards to the public system. It #8217;s honestly shocking. And they send a lot of people that ask to be admitted home as well. I know lots of people who have asked to be admitted who have been sent home because they don #8217;t have the resources unless you are in a very severe situation.

To be admitted if they wanted to go to public they would have to turn up to emergency. Whether there is a cost depends on their state. I #8217;m in QLD and there isn #8217;t a cost for hospital at least I don #8217;t remember there being a cost. Not sure about other states. They would get assessed by a psychiatrist and it would be ultimately the psychiatrists choice as to whether they got admitted. Then there are private wards they could google around near where they live and find one but they are quite expensive especially if they don #8217;t have medical insurance. If they don #8217;t have medical insurance I wouldn #8217;t bother unless they could afford it which I couldn #8217;t because it #8217;s in the thousands.

Public will pretty much only take you if you are a very severe risk of harm to yourself, generally suicidal intent or plan or very severe suicidal ideation. Not even passive suicidal thoughts. They admit for other things like psychosis and delusions where there is risk of physical harm to self or others and occasionally extremely severe eating disorders that need refeeding. They just don #8217;t have the resources to take everyone and actually send so many people who come to emergency home and they generally don #8217;t give therapy either. They are also more focused on containing the crisis than diagnosis - if you are a lower risk patient which is actually a lot of even the suicidal ideation patients that come in you will be out in 72 hours to a week and would not even receive a diagnosis for anything even if you asked for one because you would have only seen the psychiatrist a handful of times. I was quite unusual to stay as long as I did but when I am in crisis they get very long and very extreme. They usually try and kick people out as quick as they can though, especially voluntary patients which is the majority of patients unless you have psychosis or something or refuse to go or they think you can #8217;t make your own decisions. I don #8217;t like how the public system works. But they probably don #8217;t get much funding either.

A 5150 is an involuntary hold. Not a voluntary one. And it #8217;s for severe risk of harm to yourself or others. Generally things like severe suicide intent and plan. Even having suicide thoughts isn #8217;t enough there has to be intent and plan because it is an involuntary hold. And 5150s are more crisis containment, they don #8217;t make you feel better or fix the problem. It #8217;s there to keep people from hurting themselves or others when they are in a crisis. Do you have a therapist or psychologist? Where I live there #8217;s private residential type places with intensive group therapies but you need medical insurance and things to go there because it can get expensive. If there is anything like that in your country that would probably help fix the problem more than a 5150 would.

Yeah you #8217;re expected to have a therapist or psychologist to help. Severe cases in Australia can get case management I believe, I was offered that when I left hospital as an adult but declined and went private. It can be hard to get because they don #8217;t have the resources but they give you a psychologist. I had it as a minor though. They offer it generally after hospital admissions for people that really need help, not sure if there #8217;s other ways to get it. But they are really stingy on it due to funding. You can go to your doctor and get a mental health care plan and get 10 free sessions with a psychologist bulk billed. They could be able to help figure out what #8217;s going on and direct to a good therapy and help with coping mechanisms.

I #8217;m personally wary about self diagnosis as often there can be overlapping symptoms for disorders and what you think is one condition can actually be something else you may not have thought of. Depression and anxiety are ones that aren #8217;t as bad to diagnose as other more complex disorders such as bipolar, personality disorders etc in my opinion but you still need to be wary for example people can think they have depression when they actually have a low thyroid as low thyroid can give you depression symptoms and an overactive thyroid can give more manic type symptoms in some cases and in those people they don #8217;t actually have the mental disorder it is actually a health condition. I wouldn #8217;t worry about offending people but I would probably preface it by saying #8220;I suspect I have this #8221;. You need to make sure you go to a really good piercer if you want your cheeks done, preferably an APP certified piercer. Someone that really knows what they #8217;re doing. If they #8217;re not done in the right spot you can have a lot of complications including if they #8217;re pierced through or close enough that they migrate into the parotid gland you will have saliva running down your cheek which is very difficult to fix. People also have a lot of problems with abscesses and pus pockets, swelling that goes up and down throughout the healing period which can take months and in some people still happens years later and my piercer warned me that some people #8217;s takes months/years to heal and that some people #8217;s just don #8217;t heal. I was very lucky that mine have done really well and apart from one of them getting slightly infected at the beginning they #8217;ve healed really well but 85-90% of people I #8217;ve spoken to have had problems with their cheek piercings. They also do leave quite prominent scars if you take them out which is something to consider - it will look like permanent dimples even if you are not smiling. I think they #8217;d look cute but they are a huge commitment to make and have to be babied for months. If you are able to handle to commitment and have a really good piercer go for it. In regards to your comment about dermals though, cheeks are in a completely different league to them. I #8217;ve had both.

Yeah cheeks are pretty much one of the hardest piercings to heal. I know some piercers that won #8217;t even do them because so many people have complications with them. But that #8217;s good you #8217;re going to look for the best piercer even if it means travelling - too many people just look for the cheapest option and you get what you pay for. Good luck if you get them and hopefully they #8217;ll be alright.

BVLA is like top of the line, you don #8217;t have to save that much unless you want super nice, gold jewellery. Your piercer really should have told you that and informed you on healing and if they didn #8217;t they really are not very reputable. It #8217;s really something that is best to talk with with a professional if possible. None of us are really able to know and you haven #8217;t really provided enough information to solidly say yes I definitely think you #8217;re bipolar either. There are two types of manias, hypo which is the milder form and mania. You either need hypomania that lasts at least 4 days or mania that lasts at least 7. What you are describing if it is bipolar sounds like it would be hypomania. Maybe have a look at the symptoms of hypomania online and see how they resonate with you. If the mood swings are less than 4 days borderline personality disorder is another condition that people can get confused with bipolar. You don #8217;t get manic generally with borderline but there is a lot of emotional Dysregulation and it #8217;s possible to have both. Anger is another one of the criteria. You need 5 out of 9 for a diagnosis and it can often be caused by trauma and invalidation. I am actually diagnosed with both. If possible it would be good to speak to a psychiatrist if possible. If it is bipolar and it #8217;s impacting your life they often look at medications to help get you on a baseline. For borderline they look at dialectal behaviour therapy. Whatever it is I hope you get some support and what you are looking for.

They are trained to be able to tell whether you are severe risk of harm to yourself or others and whether you are capable of making rational decisions or not which I obviously wasn #8217;t when I was admitted and obviously she wasn #8217;t either when she was admitted. That #8217;s not to say those admissions can #8217;t be traumatising. I found my admissions very traumatic and saw things that were very traumatic and dealt with threats and emotional abuse by staff that has contributed to other traumas into complex ptsd for me personally which I am working through and because of that I don #8217;t trust medical and psychiatric professionals apart from my psychiatrist and refuse medical help because my experiences were so traumatic. But I have also spent much longer in - some of my stays were extended more than once to three and a half months against my will which they can do in Australia if a tribunal panel decides you are still unsafe and not capable of making decisions about your treatment. But no, you will not fail an evaluation for being nervous. Otherwise there would be a line out of the hospital because almost everyone would fail the evaluations because everyone is nervous when they have a psychiatric professional they don #8217;t know asking such personal questions.

Septums really shouldn #8217;t be flipped up and down during healing. You should pick whether to have it flipped up to heal or flipped down and keep it that way for the healing process otherwise it #8217;s going to cause the piercing trauma. If you can #8217;t get it down and want it down for the rest of your healing I recommend going back to your piercer if you are having trouble getting it down.

At 2 months if you wanted it to be changed I would recommend going back to your piercer. It #8217;s still quite new and if you don #8217;t know how to get this style of jewellery out you are likely to cause the piercing site more trauma.
